div.p: BROVVNISME TVRNED The In-side out-ward.
BEING A PARALELL BETWEENE THE PROFESSION AND PRACTISE of the Brownists Religion.
By CHRISTOPHER LAVVNE, lately returned from that wicked SEPARATION.

q.p: Woe bee vnto you Scribes and Pharises, Hypocrites: for yee are like vnto painted Tombes, which appeare beautifull outward, but are within full of dead mens bones, and of all filthinesse.
Into their secret let not my soule come; my glory, be not thou ioyned with their assembly, &c.

div.p: LONDON Printed for Walter Burre, and are to bee sold at his Shop in Pauls Church-yard at the signe of the Crane. 1613.

div.head: The Preface to the Reader.
div.p:
IT is not Sathans weakest delusion, in these our dayes, to set the fairest glosses vpon the foulest matters; and to dresse his deadliest hookes with the most delightfull baites: It is my purpose therefore (gentle Reader) to let thee vnderstand somewhat concerning this Sect of Brownisme; which miserable experience, (the mistresse of fooles) hath made knowne vnto me, desiring that my mis-hap may preuent others harmes. I haue not, in the manifesting of the impieties of this Sect, written any thing, but that which I can of my owne knowledge, with good conscience, affirme; although I haue aledged sundry authors for the proofe therof; yet it is not for want of knowledge in my selfe; but rather for thy rresolution, that in the mouth of so many witnesses, euerything might be c≈çfirmed vnto thee, that thereby thou mayst take heed lest thou tread that schismatical trace; the trauelling of which, I (with many more of my penitent brethren) do now bewaile.
And I haue the rather chosen, at this time, to deale in this maner, with this their discription; because knowing that many of their Schismaticall bookes are brought in, and spread abroad in this land, whereby many good Christians are troubled and intangled, not discerning the errors therein, which they haue so cunningly hid and cloked with the manifold allegations of holy Scripture, the abuse where of is not (by the vnlearned) easily perceiued; among which this description is not the least, but rather a principal perswasion to inuite guests vnto their Pharisaicall fellowship; hauing heard sundry (my selfe) confesse that this booke of their description hath beene the onely cause that brought them vnto Brownisme. But now the visard of their profession being pluckt off, and the hookes of their heresie laid bare; I am not without hope that the reader shall reape such resolution thereby, that some shall thereby be staid from vndertaking that hard and dangerous voyage of Separation, from the which so few haue euer returned to communion with the Churches of Christ. And thus wishing it for thy wealth, for which end I vndertooke it, I heartily bid thee farewell in the Lord.

div.head: A PARALEL BETWEENE THE OVTSIDE AND THE INSIDE of the Brownists profession.
The out-side is described and set forth by themselues on this manner.
div.p:
1 AS there is but a one God, and father of all, one Lord ouer all, and one Spirit: So is there also but b one Truth, one Faith, one Saluation, one
Church, called in one Hope, ioyned in Profession, guided by one c Rule, euen the word of the most High. a Gen. 1.1. Exod. 20.3. b 1. Tim. 2.4. Phil. 1.27. Ephes. 2.18. Iohn. 8.41. c Deuteron. 6.25. Rom. 10.8. 2. Tim. 3.15. Iohn. 8.51. 1 Iohn. 2.3.4. &c.

div.head: The In-side is turned outward; and fet forth by those that haue liued long among them and know their liues, doctrines, and conuersation.
div.p:
1 As there is but one God, and Father of all, one Lord ouer all, and one Spirit: so is there but one Truth, one Faith, one Saluation, one Church, called in hope, ioyned in one
Communion. Therefore the Brownists beeing a schismed from this one Communion of Saints, cannot bee that true b Church, by this word of the most high, alledged by themselues. Gen. 1.1. Exod. 20.3. 1. Tim. 2.4. Phil. 1.27. Eph. 2.18. Iohn. 8.41. Deut. 6.25. Rom. 10.8. 2. Tim. 3.15. Iohn. 8.51. 1. Iohn. 2.3.4. &c. a See the prophane Schisme of the Brownists, Sect. 1 Chap. 2. b See the prophane schisme. Chap. 7.
Ergo, the Brownists are not the Church of God, by their owne construction of these Scriptures.

2 This Church, as it is vniuersally vnderstood, containeth in it all the a Elect of God, that haue beene, or shall be: But being considered more particularly,
as it is seene in this present world, it consisteth of a company and fellowship of b faithfull, and holy people, c gathered in the name of Christ Iesus, their onely d King, e Priest, and f Prophet, g worshipping him aright, being h peaceably and quietly gouerned by his Officers and Lawes, i keeping the vnity of faith in the bond of Peace, and k Loue vnfeigned. a Gen. 17. chap. 1. Pet. 1.2. Reu. 7.9. 1. Cor. 10.3. Iohn. 17.10.20. b Psal. 111.1. & 149.1. Esa. 62.12. Ephes. 1.1. 1. Cor. 1.2. Deut. 14.2. c Deut. 12.5. Iohn. 6.37. & 3.14. & 12.32. Luke 17.37. d Gen. 44.10. Psalm. 45.6. Zach. 9.9. Heb. 1.8. e Rom. 8.34. Iohn. 17. Chap. Heb. 5.9. & 8.1. & 4.14. f Deut. 18.15. Mat. 17.5. Heb. 1.2. Gen. 14.18.
g Exod. 20.4.5.6.7.8. Luke. 10.5. Iohn. 4.23. h Math. 11.29. 1. Cor. 11.16. Marke 13.34. Reu. 22.9. i Ephes. 4.3. 1. Cor. 1.13. Marke. 9.50. k Iohn. 13.34. 1. Cor. 13.4. 1. Pet. 1.22.1. 1. Iohn. 3.10.

2 This their Description, as it is vniuersally vnderstood, &c. But according to their application of it to themselues, considering their In-side more particularly, as
they are to bee seene in this present world, in the Cittie of Amsterdam; They consist of a Company, and Fellowship of a irreligious and prophane people, gathered together in b Schisme, c abusing CHRIST, and all his Offices, prophaning his worship and Ordinances, through their d contention, and bitter enuying, and wrangling; neither keeping vnity of Faith in the bond of Peace, and but fained loue. a See the prophane Schisme of the Brownists, throughout. b They neuer admit any man into their Communion, but with protestation to reiect communion with the Churches of Christ. c None of Christs Offices belong vnto Schismatiques. d See Geo. Iohnson, his discourse.

Ergo, By these Scriptures,
they are not the Church of God, Gen. 17. 1 Pet. 1.2. Reu. 7.9.

3 Most a ioyfull, excellent, and glorious things are euery where in the Scriptures spoken of this Church. It is called the b Citty, c House, d Temple, and e Mountaine of the Eternall God: the f chosen Generation, the holy Nation, the peculiar people: the g Vineyard, the Garden inclosed, the Spring shut vp, the scaled Fountaine, the Orchard of Pomegranats, with sweet fruits: the h heritage, the Kingdome of Christ; yea his i Sister, his Loue, his Spouse, his k Queene.
and his Body, the ioy of the whole earth. To this society is the l couenant and all the promises made, of m Peace, of loue, and of n saluation: of the presence of God, of his graces, of his power, and of his o protection. a Psal. 87, 3. b Ibid. c 1 Tim. 3.15. Heb. 3.6. d 1 Cor. 3.17. Esa. 2.2. Mich. 4.1. Zech. 8.3. e 1. Pet. 2.9. f Esa. 5.1. & 27 2. g Song. 4.12. Esa. 51.3. h Esa. 19.25. i Mich. 5.2. Mat. 3.2. Ioh. 3.5. k Song. 5.2. l Psal. 45.9. m 1 Cor 12.27. Eph. 1.23. n Gal. 4.28. Rom. 9.4. o Psa. 147.14.2. Thes. 3.16. Esay. 46.13. Zach. 14.17. Esay 60. Eze. 47. Zach. 4.12. Eze. 48.35. Math. 28.20. Esa 62.

3 Most feareful & terrible things are euery where in the Scriptures spoken of this society: It is called a a cursed generation for cursing Gods people': They are for their contentions b threatned to be no inheritors of the kingdome of heauen; for raging out their owne c shame, for them is reserued the blacke darkenesse for euer. Enoch d prophesied of such, that the Lord would come in iudgement against them, to reward both their deedes and words. Peter prophesied of such, that should e priuily bring in
damnable heresies, and bring vpon themselues swift damnation. These are makers of f Sects, fleshly, hauing not the spirit. They shall be g ashamed at the last day, for hating & excommunicating Gods people. a Gen. 12.3. b Gal. 5.20.21. c Iud. 13. d Iud. 14.15. e 2 Peter. 2.1. f Iude 19. g Esay 66.5.
Therefore it appeareth by these Scriptures, that they are not the Church and people of God. Psal. 87.3. &c.

4 And surely if this Church be c≈çsidered in her parts, it shall apeare most beautiful, yea most wonderfull, & euen a rauishing
the sences to conceiue, much more to behold; what then, to enioy so blessed a communion. For behold! her b King and Lord is the King of peace, and Lord himselfe of all glory. She enioyeth most holy & heauenly c laws, most faithfull and vigilant d Pastors, most sincere & pure e Teachers, most carefull & vpright f Gouernours, most diligent and trusty g Deacons, most louing and sober beleeuers; and a most h h≈´ble, meek, obedient, faithful, & louing people; euery i stone liuing, elect, and pretious: euery stone hath his beauty, his k burden and his order, all bound to edifie one another, exhort, reproue, and comfort one another, l louingly, as to their owne members, m faithfully,
as in the eyes of God. a Song. 6.4.9. b Esay 62.11. Ioh. 12.15. Heb. 2.7.8. c Mat. 11.30. 1 Ioh. 5.3. d Eph. 4.11. Act. 20. c Rom. 12.7. f 1 Cor. 12.28. Rom. 12.8. g Acts 6. h Rom. 12.8. Mat. 5.5. Eze 36.38. Esa. 60, 8. Deut. 18.9.13. i Pet. 2.5. 1 Kin. 7.9. Zec. 14.21. k Gal. 6.4 1 Cor. 12. Rom. 12.3. &c. m Heb. 10.24. Leu. 19.17. 1 Thes. 4.9. Col. 3.23. 1. Ioh. 3.20.

4 And surely if their Church bee considered in her parts, it shall appeare most a abhominable, yea most b detestable, & euen
to bee c abhorred of euery true Christian to conceiue, much more to behold, what then to bee intangled with such a crooked generation? For behold! they are led by the spirit of d schisme, errour, and confusion: they are annoyed with the abuse of Gods law, and peruerting the rules of Christ most lamentably: with a most e frailfull, and vilanous Pastor, a most simple and piteous Teacher, most carelesse & f vnright Gouernors, most negligent and vntrusty g Deacons: there were no beleeuers while I liued among them, but a most h haughty, proud, disobedient, dissembling, and spitefull people: many of the stones seemed dead in religion, no tokens of Gods election on them, no i vertues apeared in their life, none bound to edifie other, but rather to dehort,
disproue, and cast downe one another spitefully, as to their enemies; fraudfully, k as if God saw it not. a See testimony of T. White. (proph. schisme) pag. 27.c. Sect, 2. b See the prophane schisme of the Brownists. c See Paralels betweene Manssield and Studley, prophane Schisme, c.6. d See Cut. Huttons worke, Proph. Schis. c.9. e See his fathers Articles against him. Proph. Schism. c.11. f See Geo. Iohnsons discourse. g See the first part of the hunting of the Fox. h Witnesse Bowmans robbing the poore, for which hee was called Iudas the pursebearer. His theft is recorded in the Citie-rolles of Amsterdam: for there was it handled before the Magistrate. i See George Iohnsons discourse; hunting of the Fox: See proph. schism. c. 11. pag. 64. k See Generation of slanders, Proph. scism. c. 12. See George Iohnsons discourse.
Ergo. By these scriptures they are not the Church of God. Song. 6.4.9. &c.

5 No a Office there is ambitiously affected, no b law wrongfully wrested, or c wilfully neglected, no d truth hid or peruerted, e euery one here hath freedome and power (not disturbing the peaceable order of the Church) to vtter his complaints and griefes, and freely to reproue the transgression & errors of any, without exception of persons. a 2. Cor. 2.17. 3. Ioh. 9. b 1 Tim 4.2.3. & 5.21. & 6.14. Gal. 12. c 1 Cor. 5. d Ier. 23.28. 1. Tim. 3.15. e 1. Cor. 6. & 14.30. Col. 4.17.

5 No Office is here attained by a lawfull meanes, no b law faithfully practised, or willingly executed, no truth rightly sought out, & discouered, no people in greater c bondage to their Officers, no Church more d disturbed fr≈ç peace. None dare vtter his complaints and griefes, nor freely to reproue the trƒÅsgression and errours, for feare of the e partiality & exceptions of their Officers. a See H. Ainsworths answere to Mr Stone his Sermon, his abuse of scripture for this purpose. pag. 26. b See proph. schisme, ch. 1. sect. 1. p. 3. c See proph. schisme. chap. 13. d See hunting of the Fox, first part.
Therfore by these scriptures they are not the Church and people of God, 2. Cor. 2.17.

6 Here is no a intrusion or climbing vp another
way into the sheep-fold then b by the holy and free election of the Lords holy & free people, and that according to the Lords ordinance, humbling themselues by fasting and prayer, before the Lord, crauing the direction of his holy spirit, for the triall and approuing of gifts, &c. a Ioh. 10.1. b Act 1.23. & 6.3. & 14.23.

6 Here all are intruders, and climbers vp another
way into the sheep-fold, namely, by the election of scismatiques, and that c≈çtrary to the Lords a ordinance; not humbling thƒìselues by fasting and prayer before the Lord, in the communion of his Saints; not crauing the direction of his holy spirit, in the mouth of his Ministers of the reformed Churches, for the tryall and approuing of gifts, &c. b Their schisme both depriues thƒì of the offices of Christ, & also peruerts all his ordinances in the vse of them.
Therfore by these scriptures they are not the Church of God. Ioh. 10.1. &c.

7 Thus they orderly proceed to ordination, by fasting and prayer, in which a action the Apostles vsed laying on of hands. Thus hath euery one of the people interest in the election
and ordination of their Officers, as also in the administration of their Offices vpon b transgression, offence, abuse, and hauing an especiall care vnto the inviolable order of the Church, as is aforesaid. a 1. Tim. 4.14. & 5.22. b Luke 17.3. Rom. 10.17. Col. 4.17.

7 Thus they a vnorderly proceed to ordination, abusing the ordinance of God, and b assuming that vnto their confused multitude, which onely belongs to the Ministers of Christ, making them Ministers
by the imposition of hands of common people: And be theyonce in office, liue they neuer so c wickedly, they are still retained, and also preferred to d higher place in office; such confused order is in their Church. a Witnesse Mr. Halies Intrusion. b See H. Ainsworths answere to M. Stone, pag. 26. c See prophane Schisme, pag. 16. d Bowman being a chiefe Deacon, is now made an Elder.
Ergo. By these scriptures they are not the Church of God. 1. Tim. 4.14. &c.

8 Likewise, in this Church they haue holy a Lawes, as limits and bounds, which it is lawfull at no hand to transgresse. They haue lawes to direct them in the choyce of euery Officer, what kinde of men the Lord will haue.
Their Pastour must bee apt to b teach, no yong Scholler, b able to diuide the word aright, d holding fast that faithfull word, according to doctrine, that he may be able to exhort, rebuke, improue, with wholesome doctrine, and to conuince them that say against it. He must bee c a Man that loueth goodnesse; he must bee wise, righteous, holy, temperate; he must bee of life vnreproueable, as Gods Steward; he must be generally well reported of, and one that ruleth his owne houshold vnder obedience, with all honesty: he must be modest, humble, meeke, gentle, and louing; hee must alwaies be carefull and watchfull ouer the flocke, wherof the Lord hath made him Ouerseer, with all willingnes,
and cheerefulnesse, not holding his office in respect of persons, but doing his duty to euery soule, as he will answere before the chiefe sheepheard, &c. a Math. 5.19. 1 Tim. 1.18. b Deut. 33.10 Mal. 2.7. 1 Tim. 3.1. &c. c 2 Tim. 2.15. d Tit. 1.9. 2 Tim. 4.2. e Tit. 1.7.8. f Numb. 12.3.7. Esay 50.4.5.6. Ier. 3.15. Ezech. 34.18. Acts 20. 1. Pet. 5.1.2.3.4. 1 Tim. 5.21.

8 Likewise, in this Church they haue a vngadly Lawes, as limits and bounds, which at no hand is lawfull (for their people) to transgresse. They haue lawes to direct them in the choyce of euery Officer, what kinde of men the Lord forbiddeth.
Their pastour being so apt to teach error, that in forsaking one, b he runs into two or three, forsaking that faithful word, according to doctrine, whereby he doth dehort from the truth, and lahbour to disproue and conuince the same: Hee is a man that loueth c vice: he is d foolish, vnrighteous, vnholy, e intemperate: he is of life reproueable, as all the Churches of God do testifie; and so generally euill reported of: one that ruleth his owne house f dishonestly; he is immodest, g haughty, proud, cruell, and h vnnaturall: hee is alwaies carelesse and negligent ouer the flocke, whereof hee pretends to be Ouerseer, with all vnwillingnesse, i grudging for maintenance, holding his office in respect of lucre, but doing his duty to neuer a soule, for which
he must answere before the chiefe sheep heard, if he preuent it not by repentance. k It is Apostacy for any of their people to heare a Sermon in any of the reformed Churches; yea, and they shall be more diligently brought to repentance for it, then for whoredome, theft, bribery, or the like a See his exposition of Mat. 18. b Geo. Iohnsons discourse (vpholding his wiues pride, wickednesse, and folly) c See proh. schis. c. 11. d See prop. schis. c. 1. e See Geo. Iohnsons discourse. f See Proph. schism. cap. 11. g See Ioh. Iohnsons 14. Article, Prop. schis. cap. 11. h See Geo. Iohnsons discourse.
Ergo, By these scriptures they are not the Church of God. Math. 5.19.

9 Their Doctor or Teacher must be a man apt to teach, able to diuide
the word of God aright, and to deliuer sound and wholesome doctrine from the same, still building vpon that sound ground-worke: He must bee mighty in the Scriptures, able to conuince the gainesayers, and carefull to deliuer his doctrine pure, sound, and plaine; not with curiosity or affectation; but so, that it may edifie the most simple, approuing it to euery mans conscience: he must be of life vnreproueable, one that can gouerne his owne houshold: he must be of maners sober, temperate, modest, gentle, louing. &c. 1 Tim. 3. Tit. 1. chap. 2 Tim. 2 15. 1 Cor. 1 17. & 2.4.

9 Their Doctor, or teacher is a man vnapt to teach (and vnable to diuide)
the word of God aright; and he deliuers vnsound and vnwholsome doctrine (of schisme) from the same; he is weake in the Scriptures, vnable to a conuince his gainsaiers, & carelesse to deliuer his doctrine pure, sound, and plaine, but with curiosity, or affectation; not so, that it may edifie the most simple, or aprouing it to euery mans conscience: therefore of life reproueable: one that cannot gouerne his owne houshold out of schisme, vn-christianly rending from the c≈çmunion of Saints, to the b great griefe of many good Christians. a Those that haue left their schisme; to wit, C.L. & R.B. haue sundry times gone vnto him, desiring conference, but neuer could obtaine it of him. b Many good Christians do lamƒìt his fall in the place where he liued in EnglƒÅd,
commending his innocent life, praying for his enlargement from his miserable schisme, which God grant, if it be his will.
Ergo, By these scriptures they are not the Church of God. 1 Tim. 3. &c.

10 Their Elders must bee of wisedome and iudgment, endued with the Spirit of God, able to discerne betweene cause & cause, betweene plea and plea, & accordingly to preuent and redresse euils; alwayes vigilant, and intending to see the statutes, ordinances, & lawes of God kept in the Church, and that not onely by the people in obedience, but to see the officers doe their duties. These men must be of life likewise vnreproueable, gouerning their owne families orderly. They
must be also of maners sober, gentle, modest, louing, temperate, &c. Num. 11.24.25. 2. Chron. 19.8. Acts 15. chap. 1. Tim. 3. & 5. chap.

10 Their Elders are void of wisdome & iudgment, endued with the spirit of error, vnable to discerne betweene cause and cause, betweene plea and plea, without a partiality: which accordingly nourish euils; alwayes vigilant in contending to see their statutes and Canons kept in the Church. And thus they do b keepe not only the people in bondage, but see the Officers sinnes and c wickednesse cloked & hid. These men are also of life reproueable, gouerning their owne families d vnorderly; also of maners rude, cruel, e lasciuious,
spightfull, intemperate, &c. a See hunting of the Fox, the first part, b see G. Iohnsons discourse. c Witnesse Studleyes vncleannesse, and de Cluse his drunkennesse, so long smothered vp among them. d See M. Hintons testimony giuen in Dutch, proph. schis. c. 4. e See Saund. Artic. proph. schism. c. 1. Sect. 2. p. 15.
Ergo, By these scriptures they are not the Church of God. Num. 11.24.25. &c.

11 Their Deacons must be men of honest report, hauing the mystery of faith in a pure c≈çscience, endued with the holy Gost. They must bee graue, temperate, not giuen to excesse, nor filthy lucre. Act. 6.3. 1. Tim. 3.8.9.

11 Their Deacons also be men of a scandalous life, hauing the mystery of iniquity in a putrified c≈çscience, being endued with the spirit of b schisme: some vaine and intemperate, some giuen to c excesse and filthy lucre. a See disc. of T. White. b witnesse M. Halies protestation to get into office. c Iudas the purs-bearer was one.
Ergo, By these scriptures they are not, &c. Act. 6.3.

12 Their Relieuers, or Widowes must be women of 50 yeares of age at the least, for auoiding of inconueniences: they must bee well reported of for good works: such as haue nourished their children, such as haue bin harborous to strangers, diligent and seruiceable to Saints, compassionate and helpefull to them in aduersity, giuen to euery good worke, continuing in supplications and prayers night & day. 1.
